references.A87SOD01USGP: Soderquist, T.R. 1987. The impact of tassel-eared squirrel defoliation on ecotonal ponderosa pine. Journal of Mammalogy. 68(2): 398-401.
references.A75RAT01USGP: Ratcliff, T.D., D.R. Patton, and P.F. Ffolliott. 1975. Ponderosa pine basal area and the Kaibab squirrel. Journal of Forestry 73:284-286.
references.B75FIN01SWGP: Findley, J. S., A. H. Harris, D. E. Wilson, and C. Jones. 1975. Mammals of New Mexico. University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 360 pages.
references.A03DOD01USGP: Dodd, N.L., J.S. States, and S.S. Rosenstock. 2003. Tassel-eared squirrel population, habitat condition, and dietary relationships in North-Central Arizona. The Journal of Wildlife Management, 67(3):622-633.
references.A06PRA01USGP: Prather, J.W., N.L. Dodd, B.G. Dickson, H.M. Hampton, Y. Xu, E.N. Aumack, and T.D. Sisk. 2006. Landscape models to predict the influence of forest structure on tassel-eared squirrel populations. The Journal of Wildlife Management, 70(3):723-731.
references.A05EDE01USGP: Edelman, A.J. and J.L. Koprowski. 2005. Diet and tree use of Abert's squirrels (Sciurus aberti) in a mixed-conifer forest. The Southwestern Naturalist, 50(4):461-465.
references.A74FER01USGP: Ferner, J.W. 1974. Habitat relationships of Tamiasciurus hudsonicus and Sciurus aberti in the Rocky Mountains. Southwestern Naturalist 18:470-473.
references.B86HOF01SWGP: Hoffmeister, D.F. 1986. Mammals of Arizona. University of Arizona Press. The University of Arizona Press and the Arizona Game and Fish Department, Tucson, Arizona. 602 pages.
references.B81HAL01USGP: Hall, J.G. 1981. A field study of the Kaibab squirrel in Grand Canyon National Park. Wildlife Monographs 75. 54 pages.
references.A77NAS01USGP: Nash, O.J. and R.N. Seaman. 1977. Sciurus aberti. Mammalian Species 80:1-5.
references.A03HUT01USGP: Hutton, K.A., J.L. Koprowski, V.L. Greer, M.I. Alanen, C.A. Schauffert, and P.J. Young. 2003. Use of mixed-conifer and spruce-fir forests by an introduced population of Abert's squirrels (Sciurus aberti). Southwestern Naturalist 48:257-260.

habitat_description:
S. aberti is found primarily in ponderosa pine forests and woodlands (Nash and Seaman, 1977; Dodd et al., 2003; Keith, 2003). The subspecies kaibabensis and introduced populations have been observed in mixed-conifer forests of Douglas-fir, quaking aspen, Englemann spruce, blue spruce, subalpine fir, white fir, and southwestern white pine (Findley et al., 1975; Hall, 1981; Hutton et al., 2003; Edelman and Koprowski, 2005) as well as in pinyon-juniper woodlands (Reynolds, 1966; Ratcliff et al., 1975; Soderquist, 1987), though typically within close proximity to stands of ponderosa.

The species avoids open woodlands and savannas, requiring corridors of interlocking canopies (Keith, 2003) or a minimum canopy cover of 40-50% (Prather et al., 2006).
